reviewText:
Product received for free

For a while I've been looking for games like Megaman X series here, and finally, I found this
Man this game is soooo awesome !
Okay, pros:
+ Beautiful pixel artwork/graphic
+ Cool soundtrack
+ Great content and gameplay
for more details about the gameplay, I'd name for good stuff. Just like in a Megaman X game, everytime you defeat a boss, you'll get his/her DNA and power ! And the hidden places and items are really fun to find.
Oh and people might suggest you to play this game with a controler, but without them its fine. The best keys are arrow keys for moving and z,x,c,v for action (just like in Megaman too! )
Well, the cons ?
+ You might find the enemies are not much different in stages
+ The boss are actually pretty easy, especially for anyone who has played Megaman before
Well, anyway, I'd give this game 9/10 !
Recommended

reviewText:
Khimera: Destroy All Monster Girls is a fun and quirky platformer that reminds me of games from my childhood.  Best of all is the price tag at the low, low price of free.  The game is fleshed out with quite a few levels, each with their own themes and each containing various secrets, such as fairies to find.  Upon completing levels you're given a ranking based on your performance.

Khimera's difficulty level probably falls more in line with your own skill and ability.  If you're impatient like I am, you'll find the game to be a bit more difficult because you'll hurry along.  This leads to missing things like jumps, some of which are very precise, or running headlong into enemies.  I will say I found the game a bit easier once I started using a controller.

Overall this game is a lot of fun to play if you enjoy platformers and with the free price, what do you have to lose?  It's not even a large download!

I did record a few stages - completely intact with my deaths - so people could get an idea of exactly how it plays:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-6i5pkJjDxw

reviewText:
Most of the game is great, and it's free, but the entire experience is ruined by the following things:

You can cheese most enemies and bosses by spamming dash punch,  the controls are not tight enough for 20 small platforms in a row with instant death pits and spikes, the controller is the same as the keyboard, there is no feathing to movement making the megaman level difficulty unfair and out of your control in some platforming sections, Having to watch the stupid skeletons slowly take your money again and again after each of those cheap deaths in those sections gets old very fast, spikes doing damage from the side without touching them.  You cannot use the pizza attack using a controller.

I have beaten super meat boy, super mario lost levels, IWBTG, all the megamans, shovel knight etc.  This game should be my jam, but the controls hold it back.  Fix that, and i will gladly buy the next one.

reviewText: Khimera is a short and humorous beat 'em up that has interesting and fun characters, challenging but fair levels, and an amazing soundtrack. Controls take a bit of getting used to at the beginning and the difficulty curve is a bit wonky at the beginning (depending on where the player starts at) but overall this is a massively enjoyable free game. I highly recommend downloading and playing it.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Khimera is a wonderful, nostalgic labor of love. It hearkens back to an era when most games were colorful and cheerful rather than gritty and grim, when games had punishing difficulty curves and when mastering a particular portion felt rewarding, when games were loaded with secrets and fed a sense of wonderment and discovery. These were the games of my childhood, and this is the niche that Khimera fits into.

Far more than a mere nod to the past, Khimera feels like a lost classic of early gaming. Its artwork, music, humor, and gameplay all work together to deliver one of the most satisfying (and for free, no less!) games I've encountered in some time.

In short, if you like fun, happiness, and childlike innocence, you should download this game. Because that's what this game is-- distilled happiness and a  chance to recapture, at least for a couple of hours, what it felt like to be 8 years old. That's a magical feeling.

I already can't wait for the sequel.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Out of all the free games I've played on Steam, this one certainly feels the meatiest.

Khimera: Destroy All Monster Girls is a Mega Man-style action-platformer with beat-em-up elements that pays homage to a number of established retro games. You can definitely tell there is a lot of love poured into this game, from the colorful graphics to the catchy music to the tight platforming and tough enemies. It's a little easier than most classic Mega Man games, but still a bit too difficult for my tastes.

I really recommend this game to platforming fanatics and people who just want to look for a fairly challenging game with quite a bit of content for the price tag of nothing.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Alright, I'll get all up in this.

Khimera is a retro-style side-scrolling platform-bouncing beat-em-up, featuring the most adorable of protagonists ever.

What's the story?
There's a peaceful and rich island somewhere, and it's full of monster girls. Then, pirates attack for the money. Meanwhile, a scientist had just finished building a chimera [Cheshia], when he's asked to help save the island. He gives the chimera a golem arm to beat pirates up with. Then you go beat up a lamia [she has arms, she can't be a naga].

Gameplay?
You have a number of actions you can use to battle the pirates.
- Normal punch
- Strong punch
- Dash punch
- Air punch
- Ground punch

While each should fill their own role, the dash punch is highly spammable, meaning it's superior to the rest in the boss fights [or at least one boss fight].

Level Design?
Some levels are just painful to try playing [Oil Rig, Airship Fortress]. Some are easier, but only slightly. If you can beat Mega Man, you may only have slight difficulties with this game. If you haven't, you're straight boned.

Distractions?
You can play a weird Mario Bros./Wrecking Crew imitation called Cake Boy. There's a chef in a place with cakes, signs, sweets, doors and snakes. The goal is to score points by collecting sweets, getting the cake to the white door or blowing up enemies with bombs. Each door leads to the other door of the same color, and cracked doors break after use.

So, overall?
This is a game. It exists. If it costed money, you can bet the top of your legs it'd be worth a fiver. But it doesn't.
Which lets me rate it:
9/10 [Almost perfect]

reviewText:
Product received for free

best free game i have played in a long time, best one on steam right now for sure. The controls seem to be really tight, the only thing that i would change is how you lose momentum if you attack midair (the sauce shot loses a lot of potential because you became helpless midair imo.)
Also if i had to change a combat element, it would be the dash attack. I don't think it has to be removed altogether, but maybe make it unable to hit back projectiles and put it on a cooldown. Lots of games like League/WoW have mechanics where an ability has 2 or more charges, each charge has X seconds before its back up, so the ability can be used in rapid succession but then they have to wait twice the amount of time for both charges to be back. I think that type of system would really benefit if the charge attack is kept, because right now it makes it too easy to cheese bosses.
other than that its damn good, there seems to be a checkpoint in enough spots where you don't get too much repetition sickness, fun/challenging platforming, and also has easter eggs/interesting interactions if you poke around.
With the dash attack busted atm id give it 7/10 because combat/difficulty level means a lot to me and it makes it too easy in some aspects, but really worth a play.

reviewText:
Product received for free

I saw a free game and so downloaded it for sh*ts and giggles... I have to say it greatly exceeded my expectations!
Basically it's a Megaman game with monstergirls, but more focused on speedrunning. If you don't like that part, no worries: it offers several other challenges such as multiple hidden bonuses and even levels, score challenges and even an entire hidden NES-styled minigame!
The graphics are simple but nice with cute anime-styled sprites, the characters are funny in their bizarreness, the chiptune BGMs are good as well and the controls spot-on (played this with a USB controller). There are a few references to other indie games, anime and memes but they never become annoying, the humour is gentle and at its core the game is a simple old-school platformer with lots of replayability and attention to detail. Example: did you notice that the sprite on the world map changes according to the dress you put on?
It might become a little repetitive in the end, but then again this is the only major flaw I could find.
Hope we see Chelshia again in the near future!

reviewText: Khimera: Destroy All Monster Girls is an extremely charming platforming adventure, especially given that it is an indie game on steam. I was shocked by just how much thought and creativity went into each character in the game. Everyone in this game has a distinct personality, making the world seem vibrant and alive. It has been a very long time since I have spent more time running around the HUB world talking to the npcs than actually playing the game. As for the soundtrack, I haven't heard toons as catchy as this since Undertale. While the combat system in this game is a little rough at times, it certainly gets the job done. I give this game two ensusiastic thumbs up. I'd give it more, but sadly I only have two thumbs.

Good job. Looking forward to your next game, developer.

reviewText: First of all, I love monstergirls. So I was happy to find out this game exists, and happier to find out it's both free and fun. The game is clearly and proudly based off the megaman platform games. Like the megaman games, you make your way through themed stages, each with thier own set of enemies and hazrds that get harder the further you get into the stage before you face a boss and defeat them for a new power like having a double jump, or a charge shot. The game itself is also much more forgiving then  most old school platformers. The stages themselves can be tricky, the pirate ship ones having lots of traps that need good timing to avoid. But the bosses are all easy. They leave themselves open for long periods which means rushing in and smashing them in the face is the way to go. The only boss to put up a challenge is the last stage of the final boss, and that's more due to the moving platfroms and the spikes you have to deal with.  The game is short, but that's to be expected when it's free.  There is stuff to do after you beat all the stages. you can find fairies and books hidden in the stages, and retry for A ranks and Deathless and Beserk runs.

reviewText:
Alright, here we go...

It's either a very fast platformer or a very slow one. If you get hit by an enemy while it's advancing and try to hit it afterwards, doesn't work. Jump back and THEN punch. I wanted to go fast, but the game forced me to go slowly and precisely.

Some mini boss attacks are impossible to read unless you've played before, for example, the mini boss in... Pumpkin something? Can't remember. Anyway, that mini boss has an attack that goes in a straight line across the screen in an instant and you have no way of knowing if it will do that attack until it has attacked.

You WILL get hit and you WILL get salty. You either play it till the end or not.




On that note, I can still recommend it since it's still, what, version 1.1?. It's on the hard side until you learn how to play it well, which I didn't.
There are a lot of positive things to say about this game, but I'm not a very positive person and always choose to focus on the negative instead of talking about the good things in life.

It's not a bad game, just a very rage inducing one. Well, for me anyway. Give it a try.

reviewText: Product received for free\n\nThis is a really solid platformer that throws you in a very familiar ground if you grew up playing games like megaman. The characters and story is fun. Nothing amazing but it's well written. The controls have been a bit rocky but they have gotten smoother. The music is definitely sweet. For the low price of free this is pretty much a must have. If you enjoy platforming games and want to try it check it out. The devs have been amazing as far as being open to suggestions and ways to improve the game.

reviewText: Product received for free\n\nThis game would be decent if it controlled halfway decent. The controls are some of the most slippery I've ever encountered. A single tap of the control stick sends me careening left or right. This, combined with my attacks having little to no range, my huge hit box making getting hit back almost inevitable, which sends me flying back twenty feet, makes the tight platforming this game demands damn-near impossible. I know it's probably tacky to complain about a game that was free, yet I still can't help but feel a little ripped off because this could have been a fun game if not for the controls.

reviewText:
The short version: I would have paid some amount of money for this game for how enjoyable it was.

The gameplay is solid (it plays similarly to Shovel Knight), the pixel graphics are good (not amazing, but definitely good), and the dialogue is an absolute riot. The soundtrack is also exceptional, making use of a wonderful trumpet synth reminiscent of the Touhou Project OSTs.

For being free, you really cannot go wrong with giving this game a play-through.

EDIT: Right, and Anchovy is best girl.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Revised for v.1.2: 22/05/16
Khimera is a free game, so any complaints should not deter you from trying it. Its style and personality counts for a lot, but the difficulty may not suit some players.

Pros:  Really nice art style with a wide range of great character designs.
Amusing dialogue and an interesting plot.
Really nails that 'retro' feeling throughout.
A sort of mixture of Mario 3, Mega Man and Castlevania.
Some good platforming (see below) and plenty of hidden collectables.
It's free, so you risk nothing by trying it.
Neutrals:  Treasure pickups are your rank, and dying removes a chunk of cash. A single death will pretty much guarentee no A-rank, and almost all of my ranks are C. It promotes perfectionism and punishes the smallest mistakes (though there is no 'punishment' beyond the rank itself).
Cons:  Insta-death platforming, where one mistimed jump will ruin your no-death run of the level and send you way back. Enemy hits stun you mid-air, too.
Sparse checkpoints and health pickups are extremely rare, so be prepared to replay 5-10 minutes over and over until you get it right. On instakill, two-block-wide platforming sections with wind, this becomes incredibly frustrating.
Enemies enter the space you occupy and damage you with contact. While your defence against this had improved since 1.2, it is still a major source of damage from enemies that attack you, remaining out of hit-range and stunning you from turning. This is compounded by flying, tracking enemies that are incredibly hard to hit --even pixels above your head-- if they're slightly off-center. Not only that, but it makes the dash-attack extremely risky, as it will usually result in you taking damage too. These might be fixed with enemeis being knocked back when they damage you, slightly wider range on vertical attacks, and some invunerability frames on the dash.
In summation, it's really cute and worth trying. The platforming is fun when it isn't a series of insta-death drops; the fighting is mashy and basic enemies can overcome you if you're not paying attention; and the difficulty is punishing, but levels are actually completeable now, so I can happily recommend this to everyone (but don't expect to fly through it).

reviewText: Very fun game. I had a great time playing it. However it can be a bit challenging, especially the speedrun cheevo. Pixel graphics but still looks good and even cute imo. A few levels, different monsters to defeat, stuff to collect, the music was good too I think. I played it few days ago and my memory is ♥♥♥♥♥♥ sometimes so I am not really sure, lol. Can be 100%-ed but takes 10-15 hours or maybe more, depending how good you are. Definitely should not be free so I paid 1 euro for that DLC just to support the dev.
